issue.title: v0.19.0 testing
issue.body:
Link to binaries:
* v0.19.0rc1 : https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-0.19.0/test.rc1/ (coming soon)

Let us know which version you tested on which operating system.

If you find an issue, please search Github for known issues first and then open a new Github issue. This meta issue should not be used to report bugs, as a single thread makes it impossible to track more than one topic.

See [Release Notes](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/bitcoin-devwiki/wiki/0.19.0-Release-Notes-Draft) for a list of changes, and testing reports for earlier releases ([v0.18.0](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/15555)), for an idea what to test.

events.body:
tACK v0.19.0rc1 on macOS 10.14.6:

* tested installing from (signed) DMG
* tested loading wallets

I'd like to repeat my point that this meta issue should not be used to report bugs, as a single thread makes it impossible to track more than one topic.

I think the OP should mention that

I've tested rc1 (for now, the tag, not the release binaries, will check those too)

- on ARM32 debian 10 (non-pruned)
- on x86_64 Ubuntu 18.04 (in pruned mode), as backend for joinmarket
- on x86_64 FreeBSD (non-pruned), as backend for c-lightning

binaries:

- tested RISC-V binaries on SiFive Unleashed w/ up to date Fedora, `bitcoind` and `bitcoin-cli` work, synced the last part of the chain succesfully

I've tested rc1 release binaries by running `export LC_ALL=C.UTF-8; bin/test_bitcoin`

Edit: After @fanquake 's hint I am adding this `export LC_ALL` according to #14948 

- on i686 Ubuntu 19.04 (with multilib, the same system as x86_64 below) no errors detected
- on x86_64 Ubuntu 19.04 no errors detected
- on ARM32 Ubuntu 19.04 no errors detected, also a pruned node (mainnet and testnet)
- on ARM32 Debian 10 no errors detected
- on ARM64 Debian bullseye/sid no errors detected
I'm also patiently running an IBD on an ARM32 device to get bonus points in #17002. I switched that instance to rc1 and it's still happily chipping away at blocks (497500 and counting...).

> I'm also patiently running an IBD on an ARM32 device to get bonus points in #17002. I switched that instance to rc1 and it's still happily chipping away at blocks (497500 and counting...).

What are review points? Also what does checkpoints = 0 do?
@Relaxo143 please ask in #17002; it's not relevant here.
Tested on Windows10 1709 64-bit, no errors detected.

Tested tagged rc3 built from source on Debian 4.19.37-5+deb10u2 (2019-08-08) x86_64 GNU/Linux.

Ran bitcoind for a day with no issues, normal log, ran various CLI commands. Ran it also with c-lightning v0.7.2.1-414-g68222dd and tested various lightning CLI commands. Blocks synced.
```
~/projects/bitcoin/bitcoin/src ((HEAD detached at v0.19.0rc3))$ bitcoind
2019-10-29T09:46:33Z Bitcoin Core version v0.19.0rc3 (debug build)
```
Ran the GUI, various console commands, and menus. Created wallets and loaded various wallets, created addresses and transactions.

![Screenshot from 2019-10-29 10-59-02](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2415484/67757128-1e4ab780-fa33-11e9-8051-8f186b9a8a59.png)

issue.title: v0.21.0 testing
issue.body:
Link to announcement:
* rc5: https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitcoin-core-dev/2021-January/000096.html
* rc3: https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitcoin-core-dev/2020-December/000095.html
* rc2: https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitcoin-core-dev/2020-November/000094.html

Let us know which version you tested on which operating system.

If you find an issue, please search Github for known issues first and then open a new Github issue. This meta issue should not be used to report bugs, as a single thread makes it impossible to track more than one topic.

See [Release Notes](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/bitcoin-devwiki/wiki/0.21.0-Release-Notes-Draft) for a list of changes, and testing reports for earlier releases ([v0.19.0](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/17079)), for an idea what to test.

Release schedule: #18947

issue.title: v22.0 testing
issue.body:
Umbrella issue for 22.0 testing. As there have been changes to the release process and distribution (thanks to the hard work of @dongcarl and others), I expect some more issues to come up than with the usual major release. Please help testing on a wide variety of supported platforms, as well as interaction with different software.

Let us know which version you tested on which operating system.

If you find an issue, please search Github for known issues first and then open a new Github issue. This meta issue should not be used to report bugs, as a single thread makes it impossible to track more than one topic.

- See [Draft Release Notes](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/bitcoin-devwiki/wiki/22.0-Release-Notes-draft) for a list of changes, and testing reports for earlier releases ([v0.19.0](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/17079)), for an idea what to test.

- For suggestion on how and what to test see the [22.0 Release Candidate Testing Guide](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/bitcoin-devwiki/wiki/22.0-Release-Candidate-Testing-Guide).

- rc2 announcement: https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitcoin-core-dev/2021-August/000100.html
- Release schedule: #20851

## Note on verifying the binaries
(updated as of rc2)

We are retiring the [Bitcoin Core binary release signing key](https://keyserver.ubuntu.com/pks/lookup?search=0x90C8019E36C2E964&fingerprint=on&op=index) for new major releases. This single key (by @laanwj) was always used to sign `SHA256SUMS.asc`.

Instead, the idea is to use the attestations of the deterministic builders (GUIX builders) directly. Instead of a single `SHA256SUMS.asc` there will be two files shipped with the distribution: 
- a `SHA256SUMS` with hashes of the distributed binaries.
```
db29446e55fd8b05c327ecfe036073fe27fbbd2f8597bf6c5f99aca64a378e7f  aarch64-linux-gnu/bitcoin-22.0rc2-aarch64-linux-gnu-debug.tar.gz
f7158d5a195aa0c59f931e5dbf3ac685e951a51f896abc38a87d04e99c0b8857  aarch64-linux-gnu/bitcoin-22.0rc2-aarch64-linux-gnu.tar.gz
⋮
d7afb5b36d49df0082e0fe68187665efb321bed783e9f79c92dfa3974877b7aa  x86_64-w64-mingw32/bitcoin-22.0rc2-win64-setup-unsigned.exe
078178ef69100e9bee36d4c74bcd3446ff1239b3a20b1efda37b7149b3b4aa70  x86_64-w64-mingw32/bitcoin-22.0rc2-win64.zip
```
- a `SHA256SUMS.asc` file with concatenated GPG signatures of the different builders/attesters who attest to the same single output:
```
-----BEGIN PGP SIGNATURE-----

iQJGBAABCAAwFiEE0dvyxLlvLev0wWZUQQEIES5+qB8FAmEKeVUSHGhlYmFzdG9A
⋮
-----END PGP SIGNATURE-----
-----BEGIN PGP SIGNATURE-----

iQEzBAABCgAdFiEEnerg3HBjJJ+wVHRoHkrtYphs0l0FAmEKg/oACgkQHkrtYphs
⋮
-----END PGP SIGNATURE-----
⋮
```

To verify, first check the signatures
```bash
$ gpg --verify SHA256SUMS.asc SHA256SUMS
```
This will show an output like:
```
gpg: Good signature from "Antoine Poinsot <darosior@protonmail.com>" [unknown]
⋮
gpg: Good signature from "Michael Ford (bitcoin-otc) <fanquake@gmail.com>" [unknown]
⋮
gpg: Good signature from "Wladimir J. van der Laan <laanwj@visucore.com>" [unknown]
⋮
```
Make sure it has good signatures by people you trust to do a Bitcoin Core release.

Then, verify the file hashes:
```
$ sha256sum -c --ignore-missing < SHA256SUMS
bitcoin-22.0rc3-aarch64-linux-gnu.tar.gz: OK
bitcoin-22.0rc3-arm-linux-gnueabihf.tar.gz: OK
bitcoin-22.0rc3.tar.gz: OK
bitcoin-22.0rc3-powerpc64-linux-gnu.tar.gz: OK
bitcoin-22.0rc3-powerpc64le-linux-gnu.tar.gz: OK
bitcoin-22.0rc3-riscv64-linux-gnu.tar.gz: OK
bitcoin-22.0rc3-osx-signed.dmg: OK
bitcoin-22.0rc3-osx64.tar.gz: OK
bitcoin-22.0rc3-x86_64-linux-gnu.tar.gz: OK
bitcoin-22.0rc3-win64-setup.exe: OK
bitcoin-22.0rc3-win64.zip: OK
```
